{{one source|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox military unit |unit_name=4{{sup|e}} Brigade Aéromobile |image= |caption=Badge |dates=1999 - 2010 |country=[[France]] |allegiance= |branch=[[French Army]] |type=[[French Army Light Aviation|ALAT]] |role= |size=4,400 men, 202 helicopters |command_structure=[[Commandement de la Force d'Action Terrestre]] |current_commander= |garrison=[[Essey-les-Nancy]] |ceremonial_chief= |colonel_of_the_regiment= |nickname= |patron= |motto= |colors= |march= |mascot= |battles= |notable_commanders= |anniversaries= }} The '''4th Airmobile Brigade''' ({{lang-fr|4{{sup|e}} Brigade Aéromobile, 4{{sup|e}} BAM}}) is a helicopter unit of the [[French Army]]. It makes up for most of the [[French Army Light Aviation]]. The brigade is heir to the traditions and honours of the 4th Airmobile Division. The French Army has announced that the brigade will be disbanded in 2010 and its constituent units placed directly under the command of the Land Forces Command.<ref>French Army website, 4th Airmobile Brigade page http://www.defense.gouv.fr/terre/decouverte/presentation/composantes/brigades/4e_brigade_aeromobile</ref> It is announced by the French Armed Forces, that the brigade will be reraised on July 1, 2016 as the '''4th Air Combat Brigade''' (4e Brigade d'Aérocombat), headquartered at Clermont-Ferrant, directly subordinated to the COMALAT (the army aviation command) and including the 1st, 3rd and 5th Combat Helicopter Regiments.<ref>Official Ministry of Defence statement, page 7 http://www.defense.gouv.fr/content/download/391477/5836838/file/Restructurations+2016+Principales+mesures.pdf</ref>
== Composition == *[[1st Combat Helicopter Regiment|1{{sup|er}} Régiment d'Hélicoptères de Combat]] (1{{sup|er}} RHC) Combat Helicopter Regiment in [[Phalsbourg]] with 22 [[Aérospatiale Gazelle|Gazelle]], 20 [[Aérospatiale Puma|Puma]] and 14 [[Eurocopter Cougar|Cougar]] *3{{sup|e}} Régiment d'Hélicoptères de Combat (3{{sup|e}} RHC) Combat Helicopter Regiment in [[Etain (France)|Etain]] with 37 [[Aérospatiale Gazelle|Gazelle]], 16 [[Aérospatiale Puma|Puma]] *5{{sup|e}} Régiment d'Hélicoptères de Combat (5{{sup|e}} RHC) Combat Helicopter Regiment in [[Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Pau]] with 52 various [[Aérospatiale Gazelle|Gazelle]] and [[Aérospatiale Puma|Puma]] helicopters *4{{sup|e}} Compagnie de Commandement et de Transmissions (4{{sup|e}} CCT) in [[Essey-lès-Nancy]]
The 6{{sup|e}} Régiment d'Hélicoptères de Combat (6{{sup|e}} RHC) Combat Helicopter Regiment in [[Margny-lès-Compiègne]] was disbanded in July 2007. The airport has changed into civil status.
==References== <references/>
== External links == * {{fr icon}} [http://www.defense.gouv.fr/terre/decouverte/presentation/composantes/brigades/4e_brigade_aeromobile Defence Ministry]
{{CFAT}}
[[Category:Brigades of France]] [[Category:Airmobile brigades]] [[Category:Military units and formations disestablished in 2010]] [[Category:Military units and formations established in 1999]]
{{europe-mil-stub}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Italic title}} {{Infobox radio show |show_name = Art Bell's Dark Matter | image = | imagesize = | caption = | other_names = |format = [[Talk show]] |runtime = ~4 hours, Monday–Thursday
10 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|ET]] to 2 a.m. ET |country = United States |home_station = Indie Talk Channel 104
[[Sirius XM Radio]] | syndicates = | television = | presenter = |starring = [[Art Bell]] | announcer = [[Ross Mitchell]] | creator = | writer = | director = | senior_editor = | editor = | producer = Paul Bowman (producer)
Evan Winkofsky (associate producer) | exec_producer = Art Bell | narrated = | rec_location = [[Pahrump, Nevada|Pahrump]], [[Nevada]], United States | rem_location = | oth_location = | first_aired = {{Start date|2013|09|16}} | last_aired = {{End date|2013|11|04}} | num_series = | num_episodes = | audio_format = | opentheme = "[[Ride My See-Saw]]" by [[The Moody Blues]] | othertheme = | endtheme = "Midnight in the Desert" by [[Crystal Gayle]] | sponsor = | website = {{URL|http://artbell.com}} | podcast = }} '''''Art Bell's Dark Matter''''' was an American [[Talk radio|radio talk show]] hosted by [[Radio presenter|broadcaster]] and [[author]] [[Art Bell]]. ''Dark Matter'' primarily focused on [[paranormal]] and [[science|scientific]] topics. The program was exclusive to [[Sirius XM Radio]], a subscription-based [[satellite radio]] service. ''Dark Matter'' debuted on September 16, 2013 and aired live Monday through Thursday from 10 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|ET]] to 2 a.m. ET on Sirius XM Radio's Indie Talk Channel 104. ''Dark Matter'' was the first program hosted by Art Bell full-time since his departure from regularly hosting ''[[Coast to Coast AM]]'' in 2003. On November 4, 2013, Bell announced that he was abruptly ceasing the production and airing of ''Dark Matter'' following a dispute with Sirius XM Radio regarding Sirius XM customers experiencing technical difficulties [[Streaming media|streaming]] his show live via the [[Internet]]. ==Background and development== Art Bell was the creator and former host of the late night [[talk show|radio talk show]] ''[[Coast to Coast AM]]''; he ceased being its regularly scheduled host in 2003,{{cite news | last = Lapan | first = Tovin | date = September 13, 2013 | title = Live from Pahrump: Art Bell, master of the paranormal, makes radio return Monday | url = http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2013/sep/13/live-pahrump-art-bell-master-paranormal-makes-radi/ | newspaper = [[Las Vegas Sun]] | location = [[Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]] | accessdate = October 20, 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131019110229/http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2013/sep/13/live-pahrump-art-bell-master-paranormal-makes-radi/ | archivedate = October 19, 2013 | df = }} and subsequently continued to host occasional shows of ''Coast to Coast AM'', although due to events in his family and conflicts with [[Premiere Networks]] and the show's management team, he undertook a series of hiatuses from the show. Bell's final appearance on ''Coast to Coast AM'' was in 2010 when he hosted the program's annual [[Halloween]] show, "Ghost to Ghost."{{cite news | last = Dickey | first = Jack | date = September 16, 2013 | title = Art Bell, Radio’s Most Popular Weirdo, Returns: Conspiracy-minded host starts satellite show 10 years after retirement | url = http://entertainment.time.com/2013/09/16/art-bell-radios-most-popular-weirdo-returns/ | newspaper = [[Time (magazine)|Time]] | location = [[Pahrump, Nevada|Pahrump]], [[Nevada]] | accessdate = October 20, 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131023004215/http://entertainment.time.com/2013/09/16/art-bell-radios-most-popular-weirdo-returns/ | archivedate = October 23, 2013 | df = }}{{cite news | last = Bauder | first = David | date = July 30, 2013 | title = Radio's Art Bell returning with Sirius XM show | url = http://bigstory.ap.org/article/radios-art-bell-returning-sirius-xm-show | agency = [[Associated Press]] | location = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | accessdate = October 20, 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140630192231/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/radios-art-bell-returning-sirius-xm-show | archivedate = June 30, 2014 | df = }} Despite his departure, Premiere Networks continues to rebroadcast archival shows of ''Coast to Coast AM'' hosted by Bell entitled ''Somewhere in Time with Art Bell'', albeit against Bell's wishes. In early 2013, after nearly a decade since Bell's departure from hosting ''Coast to Coast AM'' full-time, Bell was contacted through [[social media]] by a [[Sirius XM Radio]] representative about developing a new [[satellite radio]] talk show, which was later entitled ''Art Bell's Dark Matter''. Following the show's formal announcement on July 30, 2013,{{cite web|url=http://investor.siriusxm.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=781252 |title=Legendary Radio Personality Art Bell to Launch Exclusively on SiriusXM |work=Sirius XM Radio Investor Relations |publisher=[[Sirius XM Radio]] |accessdate=October 20, 2013 |date=July 30, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021014859/http://investor.siriusxm.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=781252 |archivedate=October 21, 2013 }} Sirius XM Radio president and chief content officer [[Scott Greenstein]] remarked that Bell's ''Dark Matter'' program would be "uncensored, unrestricted, uncluttered and utterly unique." ''Dark Matter'' premiered on September 16, 2013,{{cite news | last = CarsTravelFood | date = September 23, 2013 | title = Take a Ride with Art Bell's Dark Matter on SiriusXM Radio | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/carstravelfood/art-bells-dark-matter_b_3966787.html | newspaper = [[HuffPost]] | accessdate = October 20, 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131027201032/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/carstravelfood/art-bells-dark-matter_b_3966787.html | archivedate = October 27, 2013 | df = }} with [[Theoretical physics|theoretical physicist]] [[Michio Kaku]] as the show's first guest. Kaku had been a frequent guest of Bell's on his previous radio programs, including ''Coast to Coast AM''. On November 4, 2013, Bell announced that he was abruptly ceasing the production and airing of ''Dark Matter'' following a dispute with Sirius XM Radio regarding Sirius XM customers experiencing technical difficulties [[Streaming media|streaming]] his show live via the [[Internet]].{{cite news | last = Speigel | first = Lee | date = November 4, 2013 | title = Paranormal Radio Host Art Bell Mysteriously Disappears From SiriusXM | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/11/04/art-bell-resigns-from-sirius-xm-radio_n_4215776.html | newspaper = [[HuffPost]] | accessdate = November 5, 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131107015254/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/11/04/art-bell-resigns-from-sirius-xm-radio_n_4215776.html | archivedate = November 7, 2013 | df = }} According to Bell, Sirius XM Radio subscribers experienced problems streaming ''Dark Matter'' live, thus negatively impacting the program's caller-driven format. Bell also stated that the ''Dark Matter'' program was being [[Pirate radio|pirated]] and streamed live via third party websites. To remedy these issues, Bell sought to have ''Dark Matter'' stream live from his artbell.com website for free, a suggestion which Sirius XM Radio refused. Following a breakdown in negotiations between Bell and Sirius XM Radio, Bell stated on his [[Facebook]] page: "Sometimes when you are 'all in' you win, sometimes lose. By mutual agreement, ''Dark Matter'' will no longer air as of tonight." ==Format and subject matter== ''Dark Matter'' aired live Monday through Thursday from 10 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|ET]] to 2 a.m. ET on Sirius XM Radio's Indie Talk Channel 104. It was rerun immediately following its live broadcasts, and was rerun during its regularly schedule hours on Friday through Sunday. Bell requested that Sirius XM Radio not replay the program's show during the daytime and restrict its re-airings to nighttime when "the mood is right." As was customary during his tenure on ''Coast to Coast AM'', Bell opened the program's phone lines for listeners to call in to ''Dark Matter''. According to Sirius XM Radio, ''Dark Matter'' primarily focused on topics including: "the [[paranormal]], [[near-death experience]]s, [[Quantum mechanics|quantum physics]], [[extraterrestrial life]] and the unusual." Bell hosted ''Dark Matter'' from a new studio built by Sirius XM Radio in a guest house at his rural residence in [[Pahrump, Nevada|Pahrump]], [[Nevada]]. Bell enlisted former ''Coast to Coast AM'' [[announcer]] [[Ross Mitchell]] to create the program's introduction and [[Bumper (broadcasting)|bumper]] announcements. The [[radio producer]] for ''Dark Matter'' was Paul Bowman.{{cite web | url = https://twitter.com/prbowman | title = Paul Bowman Twitter profile | work = Paul Bowman Twitter profile | publisher = [[Twitter]] | accessdate = October 20, 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131030233514/https://twitter.com/prbowman | archivedate = October 30, 2013 | df = }} The program's associate producer Evan Winkofsky operated the boards from [[Washington, D.C.]]{{cite web | url = https://twitter.com/Winkofsky | title = Evan Winkofsky Twitter profile | work = Evan Winkofsky Twitter profile | publisher = [[Twitter]] | accessdate = October 20, 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131026211842/https://twitter.com/Winkofsky | archivedate = October 26, 2013 | df = }} ''Dark Matter'''s closing theme song was "Midnight in the Desert," which was written and performed by [[Crystal Gayle]] for Art Bell. == Guests == Following its premiere on September 16, 2013, Bell interviewed the following notable guests on ''Dark Matter'':{{cite web | url = http://artbell.com/guests/ | title = Guests A-Z | work = Art Bell - Midnight in the Desert | publisher = [[Art Bell]] | accessdate = October 20, 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131014075804/http://artbell.com/guests/ | archivedate = October 14, 2013 | df = }} {| border="0" |- |valign="top"| * [[Loyd Auerbach]], [[Parapsychology|parapsychologist]] * [[Jimmy Chunga]], radio personality and actor * [[Steven M. Greer]], [[osteopathy|osteopath]] and [[Ufology|ufologist]] * [[Paul Gunter]], energy policy analyst and activist * [[Michael S. Heiser]], [[Biblical studies|Biblical scholar]] * [[Richard C. Hoagland]], author |valign="top"| * [[Linda Moulton Howe]], [[Investigative journalism|investigative journalist]] * [[Michio Kaku]], [[Theoretical physics|theoretical physicist]] * [[Roger Leir]], [[physician]] and [[Ufology|ufologist]] * [[John McAfee]], software developer and [[McAfee, Inc.]] founder * [[Seth Shostak]], [[astronomer]] * [[Whitley Strieber]], novelist and radio personality |} ==Planned Return to Production== In the spring of 2015 Art Bell announced that his program would return to production on July 20, 2015 reborn as '''''Midnight in the Desert'''.''{{cite web | url = http://artbell.com/ | title = Art Bell Midnight in the Desert | work = Art Bell - Midnight in the Desert | publisher = [[Art Bell]] | accessdate = June 29, 2015 | date = n.d. | quote = ART BELL RETURNING | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150626000107/http://artbell.com/ | archivedate = June 26, 2015 | df = }} It would not be broadcast by [[Sirius XM Radio]]; instead it would be [[Streaming media#Live streaming|streamed live]] from midnight to 3:00 a.m. [[Eastern Time Zone]], Monday through Friday, via a link on his website or via the [[TuneIn]] app on a smartphone or tablet.{{cite web|url=http://artbell.com/art-bells-new-show-faq/ |title=Art Bell's New Show FAQ |work=Art Bell - Midnight in the Desert |publisher=[[Art Bell]] |accessdate=June 29, 2015 |date=June 20, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150723070432/http://artbell.com/art-bells-new-show-faq/ |archivedate=July 23, 2015 }} The program would also be broadcast live by AM, FM, and shortwave terrestrial radio stations{{cite web | url = http://artbell.com/radio-stations/ | title = Radio Stations | work = Art Bell - Midnight in the Desert | publisher = [[Art Bell]] | accessdate = June 29, 2015 | date = n.d. | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150723070629/http://artbell.com/radio-stations/ | archivedate = July 23, 2015 | df = }} agreeing to his terms{{cite web | url = http://artbell.com/terrestrial-affiliates-inquire-here/ | title = Terrestrial Affiliates Inquire Here | work = Art Bell - Midnight in the Desert | publisher = [[Art Bell]] | accessdate = June 29, 2015 | date = May 29, 2015 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150723070932/http://artbell.com/terrestrial-affiliates-inquire-here/ | archivedate = July 23, 2015 | df = }} for relaying the Internet stream. On December 11, 2015, Bell announced that he had permanently stepped down as host of Midnight in the Desert due to concerns about his family's safety (Bell had reported multiple instances of someone shooting firearms at and near his property in the Fall of 2015). The show Midnight in the Desert was then taken over by Heather Wade (Bell made occasional guest host appearances) for about 2 1/2 years. Following the death of Art Bell on Friday April 13th, 2018 Heather Wade parted ways with the program and now Midnight In the Desert currently continues with new host Dave Schrader. (May 7, 2018- Current) ==See also== *[[Paranormal radio shows]] *''[[Coast to Coast AM]]'' ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{URL|http://artbell.com}} * {{URL|https://web.archive.org/web/20131029215427/http://darkmatterxm.com/ |DarkMatterXM.com}} * [http://www.8newsnow.com/story/23244111/i-team-art-bell-makes-his-return-to-the-airwaves I-Team 8 News NOW Interview: Art Bell Makes His Return to the Airwaves] {{Portal bar|Occult|Radio}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Art Bell's Dark Matter}} [[Category:2013 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:2013 radio programme debuts]] [[Category:Alternative radio programs]] [[Category:American talk radio programs]] [[Category:Paranormal]] [[Category:Sirius Satellite Radio]]

{{Infobox settlement |official_name = Astroŭna |native_name = Астроўна |native_name_lang = be |nick_name = |other_name = |image_skyline = Astroŭna. Астроўна (11.08.2007).jpg |imagesize = |image_flag = |image_seal = |pushpin_map = Belarus |map_caption = Location of Astroŭna, shown within [[Belarus]] |subdivision_type = [[Countries of the world|Country]]
[[Subdivisions of Belarus|Subdivision]] |subdivision_name = [[Belarus]]
[[Vitebsk Region]] |leader_title = |leader_name = |established_title = |established_date = |area_magnitude = |area_total_km2 = |area_land_km2 = |area_water_km2 = |population_as_of = 2010 |population_note = |population_total = 603 |population_metro = |population_density_km2 = |timezone = [[Eastern European Time|EET]] |utc_offset = +3 |timezone_DST = |utc_offset_DST = |coordinates = {{coord|55|07|37|N|29|51|56|E|region:BY_type:village|display=inline,title}} |elevation_m = |postal_code = 211364 |area_code = +375 2131 |blank_name = |blank_info = |website = |footnotes = }} '''Astroŭna''' ({{lang-be|Астроўна}}, {{lang-ru|Островно}}, {{lang-pl|Ostrowno}}) is a village in [[Belarus]]. It is located in the [[Beshankovichy District|Beshankovichy Raion]] of [[Vitebsk Region]], 15 km west of [[Vitebsk]]. Astroŭna is a birthplace of [[Lew Sapieha]], statesman of the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] and creator of the [[Statutes of Lithuania#Third Statute|Third Lithuanian Statute]]. == History == [[File:Astroŭna. Астроўна (C. Faber du Faur, 1.08.1812).jpg|thumb|left|Near Astroŭna by [[Christian Wilhelm von Faber du Faur|C. Faber du Faur]], 1.08.1812 г.]] The village was founded as a castle of Ivan Sapieha between years 1520 and 1530. At that time the land belonged to Palonnaja manor of Vitebsk paviet[[Вячаслаў Насевіч|Насевіч В.]] Віцебскі павет // {{Літаратура/ЭВКЛ|1к}} С. 455—456. of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania and was inherited by Ivan and his brother Janush from their mother, duchess Feodora Druck-Sakalinskaja. In 1546 a village was founded near the castle. For the next hundred years or so Astroŭna was a property of [[Sapieha|Sapieha family]]. In 1622 a Dominican monastery was founded by Alexander Sapieha. After his death part of the manor was inherited by his daughter Anna and her husband Stanislaw Narushevich. After the first [[Partitions of Poland|partition of Poland-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] Astroŭna became a part of the [[Russian Empire]]. In 1812 [[Battle of Ostrovno]] took place on the outskirts of the village between French and Russian armies. At the end of the 19th century there were about 70 houses in the village, in the beginning of the 20th century — about 120 houses. After the [[October Revolution]] Astroŭna became a part of [[Belarusian SSR]]. Now it's a village in Beshankovichy Raion, Belarus. In 2005 Astroŭna joined the state program for rural development and became an [[Agrotown (Belarus)|agrotown]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category|Astroŭna}} * [http://globus.tut.by/ostrovno_b Photos of Astroŭna at globus.tut.by] * [https://radzima.org/be/miesca/astrouna.html Photos of Astroŭna at radzima.org] [[Category:Villages in Belarus]] [[Category:Agrotowns in Belarus]] [[Category:Populated places in Vitebsk Region]] [[Category:Vitebsk Voivodeship]] [[Category:Mogilev Governorate]] {{Belarus-stub}}

{{no footnotes|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox film | name = Back to Babylon | image = | director = [[Abbas Fahdel]] | producer = Agat Films & Cie
[[France 5]] | music = Sami Kaftan | cinematography = [[Abbas Fahdel]]
[[Amer Alwan]] | editing = Sylvie Gadmer | distributor = Doc & Co | released = 2002 | runtime = 52 minutes | language = [[Arabic language|Arabic]] |country = [[France]]
[[Iraq]]}} '''''Back to Babylon''''' ({{lang-ar|العودة إلى بابل}}, {{lang-fr|Retour à Babylone}}) is a documentary film directed by the [[Iraq]]i-[[France|French]] film director [[Abbas Fahdel]]. ==Synopsis== Back in his home town of [[Babylon]] after a long exile, the Iraqi-born director [[Abbas Fahdel]] asks himself: "''What has become of my friends? What has life here made of them? What would life here have made of me had I not decided to follow the course of destiny elsewhere''?" In his search and inquiries, his encounters with the friends of his youth, it is the situation today in Iraq that is revealed through the camera's eye: the ravages of [[Saddam Hussein]]'s dictatorship, the after-effects of the [[Iran-Iraq war]], the [[Gulf War]] and the [[embargo]] imposed by the [[United Nations]]. ==Quotes== Abbas Fahdel (voice-over): "''The past, with its overwhelming splendour and its scents of paradise lost, is too painful for Iraqis to bear. I recall my father reciting the poet Al-Rissafi: "We are not masters of our miserable present / On men of a foregone age / The face of time once smiled / But on seeing us, it darkened''." ==See also== {{Portal|Film|Iraq}} *[[Cinema of Iraq]] *[[Iraqi culture]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=1256537|title=Back to Babylon}} * [http://www.agatfilms.com/fiche-film_en.php?id=281 Official website] {{en icon}} * [http://www.fipa.tm.fr/programmes/en?2003fip_07640 ''Back to Babylon''] at the International Festival of Audiovisual Programs {{en icon}} * [http://www.cinemotions.com/modules/Films/fiche/41981/Retour-a-Babylone/photos.html Photos gallery] {{Abbas Fahdel}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Back To Babylon (Film)}} [[Category:Iraqi films]] [[Category:Iraqi documentary films]] [[Category:Gulf War films]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:Documentary films about Iraq]] [[Category:2002 films]] [[Category:2000s documentary films]] [[Category:Autobiographical documentary films]] [[Category:Films directed by Abbas Fahdel]] {{war-documentary-film-stub}} {{Iraq-film-stub}}

{{Infobox union |name= ELA |country= [[Spain]] |affiliation= [[International Trade Union Confederation|ITUC]], [[ETUC]] |members= Members: 105,312[http://www.ela.eus/es/actualidad/noticias/ela-cuenta-con-105.312-afiliados-y-afiliadas 2012]
Labor delegates/representatives: 7,049 (40.44%) in the [[Basque Autonomous Community]][http://www.elmundo.es/pais-vasco/2017/04/30/59063824e5fdeaeb2e8b45ae.html ELA copa cuatro de cada diez delegados sindicales vascos]. El Mundo, 30/04/2017. and 1,359 (22.74%) in [[Navarre]].[http://www.noticiasdenavarra.com/2017/01/27/economia/ela-se-aproxima-a-ugt-y-ccoo-que-ya-no-suman-el-50-de-la-representatividad ELA se aproxima a UGT y CCOO, que ya no suman el 50% de la representatividad]. Noticias de Navarra, 27/01/2017. |full_name= Basque Workers' Solidarity |native_name= Eusko Langileen Alkartasuna | image= ELAlogo.png |founded= 1911 |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= [[Bilbao]] |people= [[José Miguel Leunda Etxeberria]], president
[[José Elorrieta Aurrekoetxea]], secretary general |website= [https://www.ela.eus/en/ https://www.ela.eus/en] |footnotes= }} '''Basque Workers' Solidarity''' (in [[Basque language|Basque]]: ''Eusko Langileen Alkartasuna'' (ELA), in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]: ''Solidaridad de Trabajadores Vascos''(STV)) is the most influential [[trade union]] in [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque Country]], having been created, as ''Solidaridad de Obreros Vascos'', by members of the [[Basque Nationalist Party]] on June 10, 1911, in [[Bilbao]][http://www.euskonews.com/0036zbk/efem3601.html]. ==History== [[File:Ela-stv.jpg|right|thumb|ELA-STV publication from 1971]] It was opposed to the influence of trade unions who appealed to a [[working class]] [[ethos]] ([[Socialist]] [[Unión General de Trabajadores|UGT]] and [[Anarchist]] [[Confederación Nacional del Trabajo|CNT]]), advocating instead a [[Basque nationalism|Basque nationalist]] outlook. Initially, ELA-STV was centered on projects of mutual assistance between its affiliates, as a vehicle for [[social security]]. It expanded with much more success in [[Guipúzcoa]] and [[Biscay]] than in [[Navarre]] and [[Álava]]. ELA-STV was caught in the fighting of the [[Spanish Civil War]], and banned by the [[Francoist State]]. It reemerged in 1976, during the [[Spanish transition to democracy|transition to democracy]]. Today, it has over 105,000 members. In the 70's ELA abandoned its original [[christian democracy|social-christian]] ideology in favour of more [[Socialism|socialist]] positions, recognizing the importance and validity of the [[class struggle]], breaking with the [[Basque Nationalist Party]] and approaching [[LAB (Basque union)|LAB]]. In the General Congress of 1976 ELA-STV approved the new principles and rules of the union, which will become its identity: ELA was a [[Basque people|Basque]] national and [[Working class|class union]], independent from all political parties, open to all workers of [[Euskal Herria]], economic independence (funding only through membership fees, not accepting public money), incompatibility of positions, confederal basis, creating a common resistance fund, international solidarity, etc. This line will be ratified and will gain further in the coming Congress. During transition ELA was against to [[Pacts of La Moncloa]]. The pro-[[Basque Nationalist Party|PNV]] and anti-socialist wing of the union split and formed [[Eusko Langillen Alkartasuna (Askatuta) – Solidaridad de Trabajadores Vascos (Independiente)]] (ELA (a)-STV (i)), which would disappear in 1990. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Portal|Organized labour|Basque}} * [http://www.ela-sindikatua.eus/ ELA-STV website]{{dead link|date=October 2016|bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} [[Category:1911 establishments in Spain]] [[Category:Basque politics]] [[Category:National trade union centers of Spain]] [[Category:International Trade Union Confederation]] [[Category:European Trade Union Confederation]] [[Category:Trade unions established in 1911]] {{Europe-trade-union-stub}} {{Spain-org-stub}}

[[File:Theo und Ernst Ulrich Deuker 10. 10 grau.jpg|thumb|250px|Theo Jörgensmann in Jülchendorf, Germany 2009]]
'''Clarinet Contrast''' was a [[clarinet]] ensemble with rhythm group led by clarinetist [[Theo Jörgensmann]].
The group, which included members from four countries, existed from 1975 to 1977 and had awakened the interest in the contemporary jazzscene for the clarinet <ref>Festival-article by Ulrich Olshausen in ''Infoblatt [[Hessischer Rundfunk]]'', 1976</ref> and was also one of the participants in the clarinet Renaissance in jazz and improvised music scene.<ref>The clarinet seems to be having a worldwide jazz revival. [[Joachim-Ernst Berendt]]; [[Down Beat]] 2/1980</ref>
The band members were the clarinetists Theo Jörgensmann, [[Bernd Konrad]], [[Perry Robinson]], [[Hans Kumpf]], [[Michel Pilz]] so as [[Günter Lenz]], bass and [[Peter Giger]], drums. Occasionally the clarinetists [[Gunter Hampel]] and [[Willem Breuker]] performed with ''Clarinet Contrast''. [[File:Günther Lenz Unterfahrt 2009-08-25-001.jpg|thumb|200px|Günter Lenz former member of ''Clarinet Contrast'' at Jazzclub ''Unterfahrt'' ([[Munich]] 2009)]]
== External links == *[https://archive.is/20121203231405/http://vids.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=vids.individual&VideoID=54613333 "Clarinet Contrast" at Jazz Festival Frankfurt 1976 (video)]

revision.text:
The '''Committee of Concerned Asian Scholars''' ('''CCAS''') was founded in 1968 by a group of graduate students and younger faculty as part of the [[Opposition to the Vietnam War|opposition to the American participation in the Vietnam War]]. They proposed a "radical critique of the assumptions which got us [The United States] into Indo-China and were keeping us from getting out".<ref>Paul Cohen, ''Discovering History in China: American Historical Writing on the Recent Chinese Past'' (New York, London:: Columbia University Press, 1984): p. 104</ref> The caucus was held at the [[Association for Asian Studies]] convention in Philadelphia, but was a radical critique of that professional association's values, organization, and leadership. The group was largely formed due to the Association for Asian Studies lack of public stance on the Vietnam War.<ref name=Baum /> Most of the original members were graduate students or junior faculty in [[Area Studies]] programs at Harvard, Stanford, University of Michigan, University of California at Berkeley, and Columbia University, although there were also [[independent scholar]]s and those with no affiliation in the field.<ref>Richard Madsen, ''China and the American Dream: A Moral Inquiry'' (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1995): 153-157.</ref>
On 30 March 1969, the group passed the following Statement of Purpose: : We first came together in opposition to the brutal aggression of the United States in Vietnam and to the complicity or silence of our profession with regard to that policy. Those in the field of Asian studies bear responsibility for the consequences of their research and the political posture of their profession. We are concerned about the present unwillingness of specialists to speak out against the implications of an Asian policy committed to ensuring American domination of much of Asia. We reject the legitimacy of this aim, and attempt to change this policy. We recognize that the present structure of the profession has often perverted scholarship and alienated many people in the field.
: The Committee of Concerned Asian Scholars seeks to develop a humane and knowledgeable understanding of Asian societies and their efforts to maintain cultural integrity and to confront such problems as poverty, oppression, and imperialism. We realize that to be students of other peoples, we must first understand our relations to them. CCAS wishes to create alternatives to the prevailing trends in scholarship on Asia, which too often spring from a parochial cultural perspective and serve selfish interests and expansionism. Our organization is designed to function as a catalyst, a communications network for both Asian and Western scholars, a provider of central resources for local chapters, and a community for the development of anti-imperialist research.<ref>[http://criticalasianstudies.org/about-us/bcas-founding-statement.html BCAS Founding Statement 30 March, 1969]</ref>
==Founding members and contributors== {{div col|colwidth=20em}} *[[Herbert Bix]] *[[Molly Joel Coye]] *[[Bruce Cumings]] *[[Norma Diamond]] *[[John W. Dower]] *[[Tom Engelhardt]] *[[Joseph Esherick (historian)|Joseph W. Esherick]] *[[Edward Friedman]] *[[David Horowitz]] *[[Leigh Bristol Kagan]] *[[Richard C. Kagan]] *[[Perry Link]] *[[Ngo Vinh Long]] *[[Victor Nee]] *[[James Peck (scholar/editor)]] (Jim Peck) *[[Elizabeth J. Perry]] * [[Moss Roberts]] *[[Mark Selden]] *[[Orville Schell]] *[[Susan Shirk]] *[[Marilyn B. Young]]
{{div col end}}
==Evaluations and debates==
Richard Madsen of the [[University of California at San Diego]] sees the CCAS as part of a long line of populist criticism of academia, in this case projecting their values onto Mao's China. As graduate students, some of whom were in danger of being shipped off to Vietnam, "they identified themselves with the oppressed and saw the [[Cultural Revolution]] as a populist revolution expressing the aspirations of people like themselves." Their understandings of China, Madsen concludes, did not explain that cataclysmic event any more adequately than the social science theories they rejected.<ref>Richard Madsen, "The Academic China Specialists," in ''American Studies of Contemporary China'' (New York: ME Sharpe, 1993): 167-170. [https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=tIQOv2vnCFIC&oi=fnd&pg=PA163&dq=jim+peck+harvard+and+imperialism&ots=F-yYSggm-N&sig=drM7dCn1m-4UmLTO3BQ0kbTSGS0#v=onepage&q=jim%20peck%20harvard%20and%20imperialism&f=false]</ref>
Richard Baum of [[University of California at Los Angeles]] claimed that the CCAS anti-establishment stance had a polarizing effect on the field, that its early members promoted [[Maoist]] doctrine uncritically. He continued that CCAS made ludicrous claims such as all U.S.-government funded academic pursuits were being manipulated by the U.S. government if they were not outright forms of espionage, a stance quickly espoused by the P.R.C. which led to distrust and suspicion between P.R.C. representatives and academics.<ref name=Baum>{{cite book|last=Baum|first=Richard|title=China Watcher: Confessions of a Peking Tom|year=2010|publisher=University of Washington Press|location=Seattle & London|pages=236–9}}</ref>
==Publications==
* Committee of Concerned Asian Scholars., ''China! Inside the People's Republic'' (New York,: Bantam Books, 1972). * Committee of Concerned Asian Scholars., ''The Indochina Story; a Fully Documented Account'' (New York,: Pantheon Books, 1970). * Committee of Concerned Asian Scholars., ''Bulletin of Concerned Asian Scholars'' <!-- do not link: redirects to this page --> (Cambridge, Mass.: Bulletin of Concerned Asian Scholars, 1969-2000). 32 vols. 1968-2000 issues (Volumes 1-32) available online free of charge [http://criticalasianstudies.org/bcas/back-issues.html?page=1] . From 2001 published as '''Critical Asian Studies''' [http://bcasnet.org/about-us/]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References and further reading== * {{cite journal |last =Chen|first = Xi|authorlink = |title =Visualizing Early 1970s China through the Lens of the Committee of Concerned Asian Scholars (Ccas) Friendship Delegations |journal =Cross-Currents: East Asian History and Culture Review E-Journal |volume =23 |issue = |pages =217–233 |publisher = |location = |date =2017 |language = |url = https://cross-currents.berkeley.edu/e-journal/issue-23/chen |jstor = |issn = |doi = |accessdate = |ref= none}} * {{cite book |last = Lanza|first = Fabio|year = 2017 |title = The End of Concern: Maoist China, Activism, and Asian Studies |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Eb4zDwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v= |publisher = Duke University Press| location = Durham |isbn = 9780822369325 |ref = harv}} * {{cite journal |last =Selden|first = Mark |authorlink = Mark Selden|title =Reflections on the Committee of Concerned Asian Scholars at Fifty |journal =Critical Asian Studies |volume =50 |issue = 1 |pages =3-15 |publisher = |location = |date =2018 |language = |url = https://doi.org/10.1080/14672715.2017.1421809 |jstor = |issn = |doi = 10.1080/14672715.2017.1421809 |accessdate = |ref= harv}}
==External links== *"China Scholars Response to Vietnam," E. Elena Songster [https://web.archive.org/web/20090422013421/http://orpheus.ucsd.edu/chinesehistory/pgp/songster.htm]
* [https://library.ucsd.edu/dc/collection/bb12319849 Committee of Concerned Asian Scholars Friendship Delegations] ''UC San Diego Digital Collections''. Documents and photos from the 1972 delegation. Collections of Paul Pickowicz, Stephen MacKinnon, William A.Joseph.
[[Category:Anti–Vietnam War groups]] [[Category:Asian studies]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1968]] [[Category:Foreign policy political advocacy groups in the United States]] [[Category:Opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use Irish English|date=July 2015}} {{orphan|date=August 2010}} {{Infobox company | name = Cylon Controls Ltd. | logo = Cylon-identity.png | type = | foundation = 1985 | location = [[Dublin]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] | key_people = Sean Giblin, Managing Director and Founder <ref name=monday/> | industry = [[HVAC]] | products = UnitronUC32 | num_employees = 55+ | homepage = http://www.cylon.com/ }}
'''Cylon Controls Ltd.''' is a multimillion-euro<ref name=department>'' [[Department of Jobs, Enterprise and Innovation|Department of Enterprise, Trade and Innovation]]'' : [http://www.deti.ie/press/2005/20050426a.htm "Cylon Wins Landmark Project in Washington DC"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130217203755/http://www.deti.ie/press/2005/20050426a.htm |date=17 February 2013 }}, Tuesday 25 April 2005. Accessed 22 August 2010.</ref> [[building management system]] company based in [[Dublin]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] with offices in the [[United Kingdom]],<ref>[http://www.2findlocal.com/b/9164629 United Kingdom Office]</ref> the [[United States]], [[Germany]], and [[China]].<ref name=monday>'' [[The Sunday Business Post]]'' : [http://archives.tcm.ie/businesspost/2007/02/25/story21244.asp "Positive Energy for Cylon"], Sunday 25 Feb 2007: Gavin Daly. Accessed 22 August 2010.</ref> Cylon was founded in 1985 by Sean Giblin, a [[University College Dublin]] graduate and has now become the largest privately owned manufacturer of building control systems in Europe.<ref name=department/> The company provides smart energy control systems for buildings and has been used in industrial, commercial, educational and medical facilities.
Cylon's early customers included University College Dublin and [[Dunnes Stores]], and they now supply systems internationally to projects in the [[Middle East]], the [[United States]] and [[Africa]].<ref name=monday/> The company are responsible for the creation of Uniput technology which was specifically designed for [[HVAC]] application. The UnitronUC32 solution provides a wide choice of integration options including [[BACnet]], [[Modbus]], [[KNX (standard)|KNX]], [[Meter-Bus|M-Bus]] and [[OLE for process control|OPC]].<ref>''Building Controls Industry Association'' : [http://www.bcia.co.uk/bcia-members/cyclon-controls-uk.htm "Cylon Controls UK Limited"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819041440/http://www.bcia.co.uk/bcia-members/cyclon-controls-uk.htm |date=19 August 2010 }}, Accessed 22 August 2010.</ref>
[[Cylon Active Energy]] is the online energy management division of Cylon Controls, established in 2009
==Awards== In 2012 Cylon Controls made it into the global top 10 category winners in the Global Cleantech Cluster Association (GCCA) Awards, winning the Global Cleantech Cluster Association’s 2012 award for lighting and energy efficiency.<ref>http://www.siliconrepublic.com/clean-tech/item/30240-energy-firm-cylon-scoops-gl/</ref>
==See also== *[[Cylon Active Energy]] *[[Building Automation]] *[[HVAC control system]]

revision.text:
The '''Diocese of Aude''' or, more fully, the Diocese of the Department of Aude is a former diocese of the [[Constitutional Church]] in France.
Created by the civil constitution of the clergy of 1790, it was suppressed following the [[Concordat of 1801]]. Its territory was the [[Department of Aude]], with the episcopal seat at [[Narbonne]].
==See also== *[[Guillaume Besaucèle]]
==Source== *[http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/da594.html Aude (Constitutional Diocese)]; Catholic Hierarchy
{{france-stub}}
[[Category:Former Roman Catholic dioceses in France]] [[Category:Aude]]

revision.text:
The '''Egbema tribe''' of the [[Ijaw people|Ijaw]] people lives to the west of the [[Benin River]] in northern [[Delta State]], [[Nigeria]]. The town of Ofiniama is the seat of the Egbema. The Egbema have a strong Ijaw cultural identity, despite their location on the western fringe of Ijawland. The clan traces its origins to several migrations from the [[Mein tribe|Mein]], [[Iduwini tribe|Iduwini]], and [[Ekeremor tribe|Ekeremor]] tribes over the past few hundred years.Alagoa, Ebiegberi Joe (2005). ''A History of the Niger Delta'', Port Harcourt: Onyoma Research Publications. {{ISBN|978-37314-5-9}}
==References== [[Category:Ijaw]] [[Category:Delta State]] {{Nigeria-ethno-group-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Expand Estonian|Üldlaulupidu|date=May 2014}} [[File:Üldlaulupidu 2014 - 18.JPG|thumb|XXVI Estonian Song Celebration in 2014]] [[File:XXV laulupidu (3).jpg|thumb|A moment before the opening of the 25th Estonian Song Festival (2009) at the [[Tallinn Song Festival Grounds]]]] [[File:Lauluväljak Nõukogude ajal.jpg|thumb|XIX Estonian Song Festival in [[Tallinn]], 1980]] [[File:XXVI Estonian Song Celebration 001.JPG|thumb|Estonian President [[Toomas Hendrik Ilves]] speaking at the XXVI Estonian Song Festival in 2014]] The '''Estonian Song Festival''' (in [[Estonian language|Estonian]]: ''laulupidu''<ref>[http://sa.laulupidu.ee/ajalugu/xxv-laulupidu-uheshingamine/ XXV laulupidu ÜhesHingamine (2009)]</ref>) is one of the largest amateur [[choral]] events in the world, a [[Masterpieces of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity|Masterpiece of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity]]. It is held every five years in July on the [[Tallinn Song Festival Grounds]] (''Lauluväljak'') simultaneously with the [[Estonian Dance Festival]].<ref name=celebrations>[http://laulupidu.ee/english/history/ Estonian Song and Dance Celebrations] Estonian Song and Dance Celebration Foundation</ref> The joint choir has comprised more than 30,001 singers performing to an audience of 80,000.<ref name=celebrations /><ref>[http://www.delfi.ee/news/paevauudised/eesti/article.php?id=24422411 Lauluväljakul oli teisel kontserdil 110 000 inimest] (110,000 people in the Song Festival Grounds during the second concert. In Estonian). [[Delfi (web portal)|Delfi]]</ref>
==History== {| class="wikitable" |+List of Song Festivals<ref>{{netiviide|URL=http://laulupidu.ee/ajalugu/peod-aastani-2019//|Pealkiri=Peod aastani 2029|Väljaandja=Laulu- ja Tantsupeo SA|Retrieved=8 July 2014}}</ref> !Song Festival !Year !Place !Choirs !Participants

Eesti Laulu- ja Tantsupeo SA.</ref> |33,025<ref name="Uudiskiri 2014" />
|-align="right" |XXVII Song Festival |2019 |Tallinn |colspan="2" align="center"| ''To be held'' |}
The tradition of the song festival was born along with [[Estonian national awakening]]. The first national song festival was held in [[Tartu]] in the summer of 1869.<ref name=celebrations /> One of the organisers of the first song festival was [[Johann Voldemar Jannsen]]. In the first three festivals only men's choirs and brass orchestras participated. 822 singers and 56 brass players participated in the first festival. Starting with the fourth festival, mixed choirs were also participating. Starting with the sixth festival in 1896, the festival tradition moved to Tallinn.
Starting from 1947, the Soviet authorities forced foreign songs into the repertoire. Every event was to include the [[Anthem of the Estonian Soviet Socialist Republic|State Anthem of the Estonian SSR]], [[The Internationale]], and the [[State Anthem of the Soviet Union]].<ref name=celebrations /> Because of the inclusion of children's and boys' choirs the total number of participants rose to 25,000 – 30,000 people. The Dance and Gymnastic Festival of the First Estonian Games started in 1934 became predecessors of later National Dance Festivals accompanying the song festival.<ref>[http://www.einst.ee/culture/I_MMIV/plakso.html Dance Festival – Invented Tradition?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070610015943/http://www.einst.ee/culture/I_MMIV/plakso.html |date=10 June 2007 }} by Marika Plakso. [[Estonian Institute]]</ref>
==See also== *[[Latvian Song and Dance Festival]] *[[Lithuanian Song Festival]] *[[Singing Revolution]]
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
The '''European Public Relations Education and Research Association''' (EUPRERA) is an organization working to promote and combine [[research]] and practice within the field of [[public relations]] in [[Europe]].
It organizes and promotes various [[academic conference|conferences]], including an annual [[congress]] and a spring symposium, held in collaboration with selected universities across Europe, as well as the annual [[International Bled Symposium]] in [[Bled]], [[Slovenia]].
==External links== * [http://www.euprera.org EUPRERA Official website]
[[Category:Public relations]]
{{Europe-org-stub}}

Added link to 20th-century Free City of Danzig
revision.text:
{{for|the city-state of the same name between the World Wars|Free City of Danzig}} {{Infobox former country |native_name = {{native name|fr|Ville libre de Dantzig}}
{{native name|de|Freie Stadt Danzig}}
{{native name|pl|Wolne Miasto Gdańsk}} |conventional_long_name = Free City of Danzig |common_name = Danzig | |image_flag = Gdansk flag.svg |image_coat = Gdansk COA.svg |image_map = Free City of Danzig (1812).svg |image_map_caption = The Free City of Danzig in 1812. | |continent = Europe |region = Central Europe |country = Poland |era = Napoleonic Wars |status = [[Client state]] of the [[First French Empire|French Empire]] |empire = |government_type = Constitutional republic | |year_start = 1807 |year_end = 1814 | |event_start = |date_start = 9 September |event_end = |date_end = 2 January | |p1 = West Prussia |flag_p1 = Flagge Preußen - Provinz Westpreußen.svg |s1 = West Prussia |flag_s1 = Flagge Preußen - Provinz Westpreußen.svg | |capital = [[Gdańsk|Danzig]] |latd=54 |latm=21 |latNS=N |longd=18 |longm=40 |longEW=E |common_languages = [[German language|German]], [[Polish language|Polish]], [[French language|French]] |religion = [[Lutheranism]], [[Roman Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]], [[Jewish Community of Danzig]], [[Vistula delta Mennonites|Mennonites]] | |leader1 = [[François Joseph Lefebvre|François Lefebvre]] |title_leader = [[Duke of Danzig|Duke]]| |title_representative = [[Governor]] |representative1 = [[Jean Rapp]] | |title_deputy = [[List of mayors of Danzig|Mayor]] |deputy1 = [[Carl Friedrich von Gralath|Carl von Gralath]] |year_deputy1 = 1807–1808 |deputy2 = [[Gottlieb Hufeland]] |year_deputy2 = 1808–1810 |deputy3 = [[Johann Wilhelm Wernsdorff|Johann Wernsdorff]] |year_deputy3 = 1812–1814 |deputy4 = [[Joachim Heinrich von Weickhmann|Joachim von Weickhmann]] |year_deputy4 = 1814 | |footnotes = }} The '''Free City of Danzig''', sometimes referred to as the '''Republic of Danzig''', was a semi-independent [[city-state]] established by [[Napoleon]] on 9 September 1807, during the time of the [[Napoleonic Wars]] following the capture of the city in the [[Siege of Danzig (1807)|Siege of Danzig]] in May. After the [[Congress of Vienna]] of 1814/5, Danzig was re-incorporated into the [[Kingdom of Prussia]]. [[File:Duchy of Warsaw and Republic of Danzig.JPG|thumb|left|Free City of Danzig (yellow) on the Baltic coast, surrounded by Prussia, with Duchy of Warsaw to the south]] Prussia had acquired the City of Danzig in the course of the [[Second Partition of Poland]] in 1793. After the defeat of King [[Frederick William III of Prussia]] at the 1806 [[Battle of Jena–Auerstedt]], according to the Franco-Prussian [[Treaties of Tilsit|Treaty of Tilsit]] of 9 July 1807, the territory of the [[free state (government)|free state]] was carved out from lands that made up part of the [[West Prussia]] province. It consisted of the city of Danzig (now [[Gdańsk]], [[Poland]]) along with its rural surroundings on the mouth of [[Vistula]] including [[Oliwa|Oliva]], together with the [[Hel Peninsula]] and its [[Lighthouse in Hel|lighthouse]] as well as the southern half of the [[Vistula Spit]] up to [[Narmeln]]. The Republic was officially proclaimed on 21 July 1807, after the [[First French Empire|French]] troops had handed over the city on May 27. Prussia and the [[Kingdom of Saxony]] under [[Frederick Augustus I of Saxony|Frederick Augustus I]], also [[Duchy of Warsaw|Duke of Warsaw]], were appointed guarantee powers. Marshal [[François Joseph Lefebvre]], commander of the Danzig siege, received the honorific title of ''{{lang|fr|Duc de Danzig}}'' from the hands of Napoleon, however, the actual ruler of the city was the French governor General [[Jean Rapp]]. The citizens had to accommodate Napoleon's {{lang|fr|[[Grande Armée]]}} forces and to pay large tributes in the preparation of the [[French invasion of Russia]] in 1812. After the French retreat, the [[Imperial Russian Army|Imperial Russian]] forces [[Siege of Danzig (1813)|laid siege]] to the city from late January to 29 November 1813, and the remaining {{circa}} 40,000 French soldiers finally withdrew on 2 January 1814. Although the Prussian authorities made it the capital of West Prussia and the administrative centre of the {{lang|de|[[Danzig (region)|Regierungsbezirk Danzig]]}}, the autonomy of the city was significantly reduced. == See also == * [[History of Gdańsk]] * [[Free City of Danzig]] * [[Administrations of Danzig before April 1945]] {{Client states of the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars}} {{Pomeranian history|adm}} {{coord|54.35|N|18.6667|E|source:kolossus-ukwiki|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Danzig, Free City of, (Napoleonic)}} [[Category:1807 establishments in Europe]] [[Category:1814 disestablishments in Europe]] [[Category:City-states]] [[Category:Client states of the Napoleonic Wars]] [[Category:Former republics]] [[Category:History of Gdańsk]]

{{Infobox airport | name = Gjakova Airport | nativename = Aeroporti i Gjakovës AMIKO
Aerodrom Gjakova AMIKO | image = File:Gjakova Airfield RWY 35.JPG | image-width = 260px | image2 = | image2-width = | IATA = | ICAO = | type = Inoperative | owner = {{flagcountry|Kosovo}} | operator = Ministry of Trade and Industry | city-served = [[Gjakova]] | location = Lugbunar | metric-elev = | elevation-f = 1,370 | elevation-m = 418 | coordinates = {{coord|42|26|07|N|020|25|39|E|type:airport|display=inline,title}} | website = | pushpin_map = Kosovo | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_alt = | pushpin_map_caption = Location of airport in Kosovo | pushpin_relief = | pushpin_image = | pushpin_label = Gjakova Airfield | pushpin_label_position = | pushpin_mark = | pushpin_marksize = | metric-rwy = | r1-number = 17/35 | r1-length-f = 5,904 | r1-length-m = 1,800 | r1-surface = [[Airport runway|Asphalt]] | stat-year = | stat1-header = | stat1-data = | stat2-header = | stat2-data = | footnotes = Source: [[DAFIF]][http://www.worldaerodata.com/wad.cgi?airport=LY90 Airport information] from [[DAFIF]] (effective October 2006) }}[[File:Memorial of first flight to land at Gjakova Airfield on 23 September 1999, an Italian Airforce G 222.JPG|thumb|Memorial to the first flight to land at Gjakova Airport on 23 September 1999, an Italian Airforce G 222]] '''Gjakova Airport AMIKO''' ({{lang-sq|Aeroporti i Gjakovës}}, {{lang-sr|Аеродром Ђаковица/}}''Aerodrom Đakovica'') is an [[airport]] in village Lugbunar, near [[Gjakova]] in western [[Kosovo]]{{efn|name=status}}. The airport is expected to become public in the following years, to be used by [[Low-cost carrier|low-cost]] [[Airline|commercial airlines]] and [[Cargo airline|cargo flights]].{{cite web|title=Aeroporti i Kosovës në Gjakovë për cargo, çmime të lira dhe trajnime për pilotë|url=http://old.zeri.info/artikulli/23276/aeroporti-i-kosoves-ne-gjakove-per-cargo-cmime-te-lira-dhe-trajnime-per-pilote|publisher=Zëri.info}}{{cite web|title=Aeroporti Gjakovë, news report|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=USrw8Ew5m_A|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=19 December 2014}} ==History== The airport was built by the [[Kosovo Force]] (KFOR) following the 1999 [[Kosovo War]], next to an existing airfield used for agricultural purposes, and was used mainly for military and humanitarian flights. On 18 December 2013, the airport was handed over to the [[Government of Kosovo]] from the [[Italian Air Force]]. Under Italian Air Force operations, Gjakova Airfield handled more than 27,000 aircraft, 220,000 passengers and the carriage of more than 40,000 tons of cargo.{{cite web|url=http://www.aeronautica.difesa.it/News/Pagine/Passaggiodiresponsabilit%C3%A0Autorit%C3%A0kosovareaeroportoAMIKO_191213.aspx |title=Aeroporto AMIKO: passaggio di responsabilità |publisher=Ministry of Defense, Republic of Italy |accessdate=18 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101022700/http://www.aeronautica.difesa.it/News/Pagine/Passaggiodiresponsabilit%C3%A0Autorit%C3%A0kosovareaeroportoAMIKO_191213.aspx |archivedate=1 January 2014 |df= }} The local and national government plans to offer Gjakova Airport for operation under a public-private partnership with the aim of turning it into a civilian and commercial airport.{{cite web|title=Aktivitetet e Ministrisë së Tregtisë dhe Industrisë: Themelohet Ndërmarrja Publike "Aeroporti i Gjakovës"|url=http://www.mti-ks.org/sq/Aktivitetet-e-MTI-se/Themelohet-Ndermarrja-Publike-Aeroporti-i-Gjakoves-2882-2882|publisher=Ministria e Tregtisë dhe Industrisë|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150227170445/http://www.mti-ks.org/sq/Aktivitetet-e-MTI-se/Themelohet-Ndermarrja-Publike-Aeroporti-i-Gjakoves-2882-2882|archivedate=2015-02-27|df=}} As of December 2015, the airport is reported as closed by the Kosovo authorities.http://www.caa-ks.org/images/stories/docs/English/tjera/AIP/AIP%20AD%20072015.pdf{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==See also== {{Portal|Kosovo|Aviation}} *[[Alenia C-27J|Alenia C-27J Spartan]] *[[Radoniq lake]] *[[Batlava-Donja Penduha Airfield]] in [[Dumosh]] == Annotations == {{notes | notes = {{efn | name = status | {{Kosovo-note}} }} }} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Gjakova Airfield}} *[http://static.panoramio.com/photos/original/28596833.jpg Gjakova Airport aerial photo] {{Airports in Kosovo}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dakovica Airport}} [[Category:Airports in Kosovo]] [[Category:Gjakova]] {{Kosovo-airport-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Update|inaccurate=yes|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox Organization |name = Global Mayors' Forum
全球市長論壇 |bgcolor = white |fgcolor = black |image = Global_Mayors_Forum_Logo.PNG |foundation = 2005 |type = [[International nongovernmental organization|International NGO]] |abbreviation = GMF |headquarters = [[Hong Kong]] |region_served = Worldwide |leader_title = Council Chairman |leader_name = Dr. Carl Men Ky Chinghttp://baike.baidu.com/view/466585.htm |main_organ =GMF Council |website = English
http://www.globalmayorsforum.org
Chinese
http://www.globalmayorsforum.org/gmf2011/ }} {{Chinese|s=全球市长论坛|t={{nowrap|全球市長論壇}}|p=Quánqiú shì cháng lùntán}} ==Introduction== The Global Mayors’ Forum (GMF) is a three-day international conference held annually by the GMF Council on the topic of urban development.http://gb.cri.cn/18944/2008/04/23/882@2031110.htm The forum focuses on issues related to [[sustainable development]] but also covers other issues including international cooperation, modern development practices, public relations, hosting large scale activities and other topics in the fields of [[urban planning]], [[economics]] and [[international relations]]. The Global Mayors’ Forum is divided into several conference sessions, forum sessions and meetings. These various sessions have different focuses but are all related to the theme of the GMF for that year. For each conference a new host city is selected by the GMF Council.[http://baike.baidu.com/view/1974765.htm Baidu Profile] ==History== Planning for the first Global Mayors’ Forum began in 2005 after many months of consideration. The goal of the Global Mayors’ Forum was to transcend national and institutional barriers by bring together participants from the public and private sectors. Additionally participants would be recruited from around the globe in order to bring together participants from disparate geographic areas. The GMF council met for the first time in 2008 to discuss and plan the GMF 2009. The inaugural GMF was to be held in [[Hong Kong]] in 2009 but this conference was called off due to the [[H1N1|H1N1 epidemic]]. In 2010 Zhuhai's was named as the host city for the 2011 and 2012 GMF conferences. ==Global Mayors' Forum 2011== The theme for the GMF 2011 is “Road to Rio +20” in reference to the 2012 [[United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development]]. Like the Rio +20 conference, the GMF 2011 will be focused on sustainable development and the development of a [[green economy]]. The GMF 2011 will be held in Zhuhai, China. This city was selected by the five organizing institutions to host the 2011 GMF for its unique history and sustainable development practices. Zhuhai was one of the first Chinese cities to be designated a Special Economic Zone in 1979.[http://www.zhuhai.gov.cn/english/SurveyofRomanticZhuhai/DevelopmentofZhuhai/200708/t20070808_14736.htm Zhuhai Government website] As a result of embracing the challenges of modernization, Zhuhai has grown from a small village to a major economic and transportation hub. Zhuhai will host all sessions of the Global Mayors’ Forum 2011, including the China Sustainable Development Forum and the Six-Party Forum. === China Sustainable Development Forum === The GMF 2011 will begin with the China Sustainable Development Forum which is to be hosted by the Chinese Society for Sustainable Development (CSSD). The topic of this forum is sustainable development in the [[People’s Republic of China]]. One of the keynote speeches will be given by Madam [[Deng Nan]], former vice minister of the State Science and Technology Commission and daughter of former Chinese leader [[Deng Xiaoping]]. === Six-Party Forum === The feature form of the GMF 2011 is the Six-Party Forum. The six parties refer to participants and attendees from six different fields, namely: *government officials *non-governmental officials *business leaders/entrepreneurs *scholars/academics *student representatives *the global press. The six party forums is co-hosted by the [[International Mayor Communication Centre]] and the Chinese Society for Sustainable Development. Due to CSSD’s consultative status with the [[UN Economic and Social Council]] (ECOSOC), the results of this forum will be reported to ECOSOC for consideration during the Rio +20 Conference in [[Rio de Janeiro]]. ==Global Mayors' Forum 2012== As part of Zhuhai's winning bid they also received the right to host the 2012 Global Mayors forum. This forum does not yet have an official theme or date. The Global Mayors' Forum 2012 will feature the Mayors' Forum. === Mayors’ Forum === The Mayors’ Forum was set up for all the mayors and governors attending the GMF 2011. The theme for this forum has not yet been decided. Mayors from all over the world will be given a platform to exchange ideas, policies and practices that they have invested in or are interested in. === Others === Other activities for attendees include a Roundtable Meeting to match mayors and governors with business leaders who can offer solutions the sustainable development challenges encountered by governments. Additionally, the GMF 2011 will feature City Promotion and Project Presentation sessions for city officials, investors and corporations. ==Principle Stakeholders== ===Organizers=== * [[World Business Council for Sustainable Development]] (WBCSD) * [http://www.citynet-ap.org/ CITYNET] * [http://www.cityscapeglobal.com/ CITYSCAPE] * [[Local Governments for Sustainability]] (ICLEI) * [[International Mayor Communication Centre]] ===Endorsing Organizations=== * [[United Nations Environmental Programme]] (UNEP) * [[United Nations Human Settlements Programme]] (UN-HABITAT) * [[United Nations Development Programme]] (UNDP) * [[Chinese People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries]] (CPPAFC) * [http://english.cifca.org.cn/Introduction.aspx?id=49 The China International Friendship Cities Association] (CIFCA) http://www.globalmayorsforum.org/gmf2011/a/ltjg/ ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:International conferences]]

In [[Spain]], the ''historic-artistic'' is a legal statement that gives assets declared as historical-artistic monuments in a given locality the protection of Spanish cultural goods, which is regulated by the [[Ministry of Culture of Spain]].
==See also== * [[Bien de Interés Cultural]]
== External links == * [http://www.mcu.es/patrimonio/index.html Ministry of Culture of Spain: heritage and protected cultural property]. * [http://www.arteguias.com/pueblosconencanto.htm Guide declared Joint Historical-Artistic in Spain].

{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Use American English|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = Intelsat III F-1 | image = | image_alt = 200px | image_caption = | mission_type = [[Communications satellite|Communications]] | operator = [[Intelsat]] | website = | COSPAR_ID = INT3F-1 | mission_duration = 5 years planned
Failed to orbit | spacecraft_bus = | spacecraft_type = [[Intelsat III]] | manufacturer = [[TRW Inc.|TRW]] | dry_mass = | launch_mass = {{convert|293|kg}} | dimensions = | power = 183 watts | launch_date = {{start-date|September 19, 1968, 00:09:00|timezone=yes}} UTC{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|work=Jonathan's Space Page|accessdate=February 9, 2014}} | launch_rocket = [[Delta M]] | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|LC-17A]] | launch_contractor = [[NASA]] | orbit_epoch = Planned | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[geosynchronous orbit|Geosynchronous]] | orbit_periapsis = | orbit_apoapsis = | orbit_inclination = | orbit_period = | orbit_longitude = | apsis = gee | trans_band = | trans_frequency = | trans_bandwidth = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = | programme = ''Intelsat III'' | previous_mission = [[Intelsat II F-4]] ([[Intelsat II]]) | next_mission = [[Intelsat III F-2]] }} '''Intelsat III F-1''' was a [[communications satellite]] intended to be operated by [[Intelsat]]. Launched towards [[geostationary orbit]] in 1968 it failed to achieve orbit. ==Design== [[Image:Delta-M launching Intelsat-3 satellite.jpg|thumb|left|caption|190px|Launch of Intelsat III F-1.]] The first of eight [[Intelsat III]] satellites to be launched, Intelsat III F-1 was built by [[TRW Inc.|TRW]]. It was a {{convert|293|kg|lb|adj=on}} spacecraft equipped with two [[transponder]]s to be powered by body-mounted solar cells generating 183 watts of power.{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/intlsat3.htm|title=Intelsat 3|first=Mark|last=Wade|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=February 9, 2014}} It had a design life of five years and carried an [[SVM-2]] [[apogee motor]] for propulsion..{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/intelsat-3.htm|title=Intelsat-3|first=Gunter|last=Krebs|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=February 9, 2014}} ==Launch== Intelsat III F-1 was launched on the maiden flight of the [[Delta M]] rocket, flying from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|Launch Complex 17A]] at the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]]. The launch took place at 00:09:00 UTC on September 19, 1968, with the spacecraft bound for a [[geosynchronous transfer orbit]]. Twenty seconds after liftoff a fault became apparent in the gyroscope used to monitor the rate at which the rocket [[pitch (aeronautics)|pitched]] over. Control of the rocket was subsequently lost, with it beginning to disintegrate around 102 seconds into the flight.{{cite web|url=http://www.spacelaunchreport.com/thorh9.html|title=Long Tank Thor-Delta|first=Ed|last=Kyle|work=Space Launch Report|accessdate=February 9, 2014}} At 108 seconds after launch the rocket was destroyed by [[range safety]].{{cite web|url=http://www.spacelaunchreport.com/thrfail.txt|title=Thor-Based Space Launch History|first=Ed|last=Kyle|work=Space Launch Report|accessdate=February 9, 2014}} {{Clear}} ==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} * [[1968 in spaceflight]] {{Clear}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Intelsat}} {{Orbital launches in 1968}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Intelsat 302}} [[Category:Intelsat satellites]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1968]] [[Category:Satellite launch failures]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}

page.title: International Decade for Natural Disaster Reduction

revision.comment: /* See also */ added "Decade Volcanoes"
revision.text:
The [[United Nations General Assembly]] designated the 1990s as the '''International Decade for Natural Disaster Reduction''' (IDNDR).<ref name="UN_ARES44236">{{UN document |docid=A-RES-44-236 |type=Resolution |body=General Assembly |session=44 |resolution_number=236 |accessdate=2008-09-18 |date=22 December 1989}}</ref>
Its basic objective was to decrease the loss of life, property destruction and social and economic disruption caused by [[natural disaster]]s, such as [[earthquake]]s, [[tsunami]]s, [[flood]]s, [[landslide]]s, [[volcanic eruption]]s, [[droughts]], [[locust]] infestations, and other disasters of natural origin.
An International Decade for Natural Disaster Reduction, beginning on 1 January 1990, was launched by the [http://un.org/ United Nations], following the adoption of Resolution 44/236 (22 December 1989). The decade was intended to reduce, through concerted international action, especially in developing countries, loss of life, property damage and social and economic disruption caused by natural disasters. To support the activities of the decade, a Secretariat was established at the United Nations Office in Geneva, in close association with UNDRO.
==See also== *[[International Day for Disaster Reduction]] *[[World Conference on Disaster Reduction]] *[[Natural Disasters]] *[[Disaster management]] *[[Vulnerability]] *[[Decade Volcanoes]]
==References== <References/>
==External links== *[http://www.unisdr.org/ UNISDR] *[http://www.eird.org/ UNISDR Regional Office for the Americas] *[http://www.preventionweb.net/ PreventionWeb] *{{webarchive |url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20011116185440/http://www.proventionconsortium.org/ |title= ProVention Consortium |date=2001-11-16}} *[http://www.recoveryplatform.org/ International Recovery Platform] *[http://www.eird.org/esp/ninos/index.html/ Disaster Reduction for Children & Youth website] *[http://www.eird.org/hfa.html/ HFA Pedia] *[http://www.stopdisastersgame.org/ stopdisastersgame.org]
[[Category:Disaster preparedness]] [[Category:United Nations observances|Natural Disaster Reduction, International Decade for]]

{{Infobox company |name = Jashanmal group |logo = |type = Privately held company |founded = 1919 |founder = Rao Sahib Jashanmal |location_city = [[Dubai]] |location_country = [[United Arab Emirates|UAE]] |area_served = Worldwide |key_people = Abdallah Mohammed Al Mazroui Chairman
Tony Jashanmal Exec. Director {{cite web|title=Corporate Site|url=http://www.jashanmalgroup.com|publisher=''Jashanmal Group''}} |industry = [[Retail]] |products = [[Department Store]] |revenue = {{nowrap|{{profit}} [[United States dollar|$]]4.59 billion (2011–12){{cite web |url=http://www.jashanmalgroup.com|title=Jashanmal Financial Statements |work=Jashanmal Group}}}} |net_income = {{profit}} $2.23 billion (2011–12) |assets = {{profit}} $7.7 billion (2011–12) |num_employees = 2200 (2016–17) |owner = Tony Jashanmal & Partners |subsid = |homepage = {{URL|http://www.jashanmalgroup.com}} }} The '''Jashanmal Group''' is a [[wholesale]] distributor of consumer goods and services in the [[Persian Gulf]] region. The company, established in 1919 by '''Rao Sahib Jashanmal''' {{cite web|url=http://www.jashanmalgroup.com/history |title=History |publisher=''Jashanmal Group'' |accessdate=2010-08-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100831044541/http://www.jashanmalgroup.com/history/ |archivedate=2010-08-31 |df= }} with its first store in [[Basra]], [[Iraq]] as a general store selling many of the products that are still sold in the stores today. Expansion through the [[Gulf Cooperation Council|GCC]] followed the path of oil discovery, first into Kuwait in 1934, then Bahrain in 1935 and subsequently into UAE, with stores in Dubai in 1956 and Abu Dhabi in 1964. In the environment of fast expanding markets Jashanmal evolved from solely a retailer to also specializing in the wholesale and distribution of consumer products. Today the Jashanmal Group is active across the [[Arab states of the Persian Gulf]] and [[India]], headquartered in [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]], and operates over 100 stores and through an extensive distribution and wholesale business supplies over 1,000 retailers across segments from Duty Free to Mass Market to Mid-Market and High-end Retail.http://www.malloftheemirates.com/anchor-stores/jashanmal.aspx They represent various global retail franchises represented in the region as well as operating a newspaper and periodicals division which oversees the marketing and distribution of leading books, magazines, and newspapers in the Persian Gulf through direct distribution and through retail chains including the Jashanmal Bookstores. Business partners include [[Levant Company|Levant]], Higgs and Reed Aviation. The Jashanmal Group is also in a joint venture with Japan's Overseas Courier Services (OCS). The Jashanmal Group employs over 1,000 people in its various divisions and countries. == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.jashanmalgroup.com Jashanmal corporate website] [[Category:Companies of Kuwait]] {{asia-company-stub}} {{Kuwait-stub}} == References ==

revision.text:
{{Infobox radio station |name = "Lincolnshire Poacher" |image = {{Listen |filename = Poacher.ogg |title = Lincolnshire Poacher |description = Interval signal }} |area = [[RAF Akrotiri]], [[Cyprus]] |frequency = Several shortwave frequencies between 5422 and 16084 [[kHz]] |airdate = |format = [[Numbers station]] |language = [[English language|English]] |affiliations = [[Royal Air Force]] (Speculated) |owner = [[MI6]] (Speculated) |sister_stations = [[Cherry Ripe (numbers station)|Cherry Ripe]] }} The '''Lincolnshire Poacher''' was a powerful [[Shortwave radio|shortwave]] [[numbers station]] that transmitted from Cyprus from the mid-1970s to June 2008. The station gained its commonly known name as it uses [[Bar (music)|bars]] from the English folk song "[[The Lincolnshire Poacher]]" as an [[interval signal]]. The [[radio station]] was believed to be operated by the [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Secret Intelligence Service]] and emanated from the island of [[Cyprus]].{{cite web |url=http://www.numbers-stations.com/E03 |title=E03 The LincolnShire Poacher |accessdate=6 September 2014}} Amateur [[Radio Direction Finding|direction finding]] linked it with the [[Royal Air Force]] base at [[RAF Akrotiri|Akrotiri]], [[Cyprus]], where several [[HRS antenna|curtain antennas]] had been identified as being its transmitter.{{cite web | title = Lincolnshire Poacher | publisher = Numbers and Oddities | url = http://www.numbersoddities.nl | accessdate = 2008-05-25 }} It consisted of an electronically synthesised English-accented female voice reading groups of five numbers: e.g. '0-2-5-8-8'. The final number in each group was spoken at a higher pitch. It is likely that the station was used to communicate to undercover agents (spies) operating in other countries, to be decoded using a [[one-time pad]].{{cite web | title = The Lincolnshire Poacher | author = Simon Mason | url = http://www.simonmason.karoo.net/page14.html | accessdate = 2008-05-25 }} An Asian numbers station of identical format is believed to have been broadcast from [[Australia]], and nicknamed "[[Cherry Ripe (numbers station)|Cherry Ripe]]". It uses several bars from the English folk song of the same name as its interval signal.{{cite web | title = Profile of Cherry Ripe | publisher = Spynumbers | url = http://www.spynumbers.com/profiles/index.html?ENIGMA=E4 | accessdate = 2008-05-25 }} Cherry Ripe continued to be on-air until December 2009.[http://www.cvni.net/radio/nsnl/nsnl147/nsnl147vs.html Hundred forty-seventh edition of the N&O column / Spooks newsletter] == History == The precise date that the Lincolnshire Poacher began broadcasting is unknown; however, it is estimated that the broadcasts started around the early to mid-1970s.{{cite web|url=http://www.simonmason.karoo.net/page14.html|title=E3 Lincolnshire Poacher|last=Mason|first=Simon|date=30 October 2009|accessdate=2 May 2010}} While numbers stations have existed since [[World War I]] (making them some of the earliest radio transmissions{{cn|date=September 2015}}) numbers stations such as Lincolnshire Poacher began appearing during the [[Cold War]], when nations such as the [[Soviet Union]] and the [[United Kingdom]] needed to send messages discreetly to their operatives in other countries.{{cite web|url=http://www.esquire.com/the-side/feature/numbers-station-07-31-08|title=Secrets in the Static|last=Pepitone|first=Juilanne|date=31 July 2008|publisher=[[Esquire Magazine]]}} However, after the Cold War, the number of numbers stations greatly decreased. The Lincolnshire Poacher remained operating after the end of the Cold War, and continued to be broadcast into the next two decades. [[File:Map of Akrotiri-en.svg|thumb|left|220px|Akrotiri, Cyprus, the believed location of the Lincolnshire Poacher's broadcasts and radio antennas.]] The Lincolnshire Poacher stopped broadcasting in July 2008. The last recorded transmission of the station was on 29 June 2008. It is believed that the station's sister station, [[Cherry Ripe (numbers station)|Cherry Ripe]], began to send broadcasts that used to be intended to be sent over the Lincolnshire Poacher station. This is believed to be true because the "Cherry Ripe" station used a very similar call signal, and broadcast its messages in 200 sets of five-number IDs. In 2013 ''[[The Daily Dot]]'' published an article suggesting the Lincolnshire Poacher had moved from radio to telephone, publishing a phone number registered in [[Aldershot]], and a recording of a call to the number which featured the distinctive interval signal followed by fifteen groups of five number sequences.{{cite web|url=http://kernelmag.dailydot.com/features/report/4903/we-called-a-secret-mi6-phone-number/|title=We called a secret MI6 phone number|last=Cook|first=James|date=5 September 2013|accessdate=5 September 2017}} A follow up article was published a day later which highlighted the sudden removal of the communication system. Instead of hearing two bars of the classic English folk tune, callers were instead relayed a message telling them to use “backup channel romeo x-ray three nine”, followed by “end”. Text messages were received by the reporters stating the telephone number was restricted, asking them not to call it again.{{cite web|url=http://kernelmag.dailydot.com/features/report/4947/did-we-take-out-mi6s-secret-line/|title=Did we take out MI6’s secret line?|last=Cook|first=James|date=6 September 2013|accessdate=5 September 2017}} === Location === Although the usage of numbers stations has not been confirmed by any world government, amateur enthusiasts have traced the location of the Lincolnshire Poacher's signal transmission to [[RAF Akrotiri]], a [[Royal Air Force]] base located on the [[Mediterranean]] island of [[Cyprus]]. The station is believed to have been operated by the [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Secret Intelligence Service]] ([[MI6]]) and maintained by the Royal Air Force members that occupy the base in Cyprus. ==Broadcast schedule== The Lincolnshire Poacher was broadcast several times throughout the day, and was transmitted seven days a week, at various times and on various shortwave frequencies. This schedule was accurate as of January 2006, which is the most recent update to the broadcast schedule. All times are [[Coordinated Universal Time]] (UTC), and all radio frequencies in [[megahertz]] (MHz). {| style="text-align: center;" class="wikitable" |- ! !! Monday !! Tuesday !! Wednesday !!
